title: Jobless dad-of-four who suffered mental breakdown has powerful message for benefits critics after turning life around
text:
Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
A dad of four left "depressed and hopeless" while jobless has hit out at benefits critics following a dramatic transformation in his fortunes. 
Scott Gavin hit rock bottom while attempting to live on benefits and provide for his wife and children. 
But after being given his entire £26,000 annual allowance in one lump sum as part of a TV show, his life has changed dramatically. 
Scott, from Liverpool, invested all of the cash in an entertainment business that provides exotic animals for events. 
It has proved so successful that he even hopes to expand it this year by opening an exotic animal park. 
And he says rather than being "freeloaders and skivers", there are tens of thousands of other talented people just like him who are trapped on benefits but don't have the opportunity to fulfill their ambitions. Scott and Leanne with their four children Ellie-Mae, Robert, Chloe and Jay (Photo: Channel 5) Scott Gavin with Barny the barn owl, his wife Leanne and Mango, a Royal Python snake (Photo: Liverpool Echo) 
Speaking to Mirror Online, Scott - who starred on Channel 5 TV show the Big Benefits Handout - says being on benefits left him "depressed and hopeless". 
He said: "When I was on benefits I became very depressed and had a breakdown at one point. 
"I just felt that I was useless and was in the way. I thought my wife and kids would be better off without me. 
"I wound’t say I was suicidal but I did not want to be here anymore. 
"Being on benefits can be very depressing if you do not want to be on them. Scott invested money in an animal entertainment business which is now booming (Photo: Liverpool Echo) Scott's success has dramatically changed his family's life (Photo: Channel 5) 
"I felt like I had let my wife and kids down. I was embarrassed to be on benefits." 
Scott worked as an electrician but had "always wanted to work with animals". 
After going on benefits to become a full time carer for his son, he also studied at Liverpool John Moores University to try and fulfill his dream of working with animals. 
But the pressure of being on benefits proved to much and he suffered his breakdown and was forced to leave university. 
Just seven months later he joined the TV programme and his life was dramatically transformed. 
And he says there are tens of thousands of other people just like him who are struggling and just need some help. 
He says the government should do more to help people who have ideas for a business or job opportunity but can't take the risk of coming off benefits. Scott says other people trapped on benefits should be given more help to fulfill their ambitions 
"I think there are a lot of people in the same situation as me who have brilliant ideas or could be amazing in certain jobs and would love to be given the opportunity," he said. 
"I am not a one-off. There are people out there with better ideas than me but they are stuck there with nothing to do because they are on benefits and cannot afford to come off and take a risk. 
"A lot of people think those on benefits are freeloaders and skivers but that's not always the case. 
"For many people benefits provide a safety net." 
Critics were quick to judge when the show's trailer aired, accusing Scott and his wife Leanne of wasting the money. 
Speaking previously, Scott's wife Leanne, 26, told of the difference the money had made. Scott and Leanne toast after receiving the money from the TV show (Photo: Channel 5) 
"It's one of the best decisions we've ever made. (Because) now we're standing on our own two feet rather than relying on state benefits." 
With the help of the show's financial adviser Lee Healey, Party Central Entertainments Ltd went from strength to strength in just months. 
Scott, 31, said: "We've learnt all about how to budget and how to do our finances. And now we've got our own business and it's getting better and better. We do christenings, car shows, birthday parties. Scott and Leanne 
"We took three deposits yesterday. We've got bookings right up to October. I prefer working for myself rather than being on benefits. Life used to just go by day by day. It was time to start doing stuff for ourselves." 
Scott and Leanne said they're "not interested" in the negative reaction the show generated. 
"I'm just concentrating on looking after my wife and kid," Scott said. Scott with a four-foot boa constrictor (Photo: Liverpool Echo) 
Asked about the "champagne" celebrations, Leanne said: "We'd just been given the opportunity to change our lives. It was a life-changing moment - who wouldn't celebrate?"
